Sentencas: Solid oxide cells are electrochemical devices used for the conversion of chemical energy to electrical energy (Solid Oxide Fuel Cells-SOFC) and vice versa (Solid Oxide Electrolysis Cells-SOEC).
Titulo: Comparison of microstructural evolution of fuel electrodes in solid oxide fuel cells and electrolysis cells

Sentencas: However, long-term performance degradation impedes the widespread commercialization of the technology.
Titulo: Comparison of microstructural evolution of fuel electrodes in solid oxide fuel cells and electrolysis cells

Sentencas: To investigate the effects of operation mode on the degradation of Ni/yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) electrodes, two cells from the same production batch are tested for 1000 h at 800 degrees C; one as SOFC and the other as SOEC.
Titulo: Comparison of microstructural evolution of fuel electrodes in solid oxide fuel cells and electrolysis cells

Sentencas: The cells are fed with the same gas composition at the fuel inlet side (p(H2O)/p(H-2) = 0.5/0.5) while the direction of the current (+/- 1 A cm(-2)) is reversed.
Titulo: Comparison of microstructural evolution of fuel electrodes in solid oxide fuel cells and electrolysis cells

Sentencas: It is found that Ni coarsening occurs to a similar extent in both operation modes while Ni depletion is only observed in SOEC mode, in the region close to the electrode/electrolyte interface.
Titulo: Comparison of microstructural evolution of fuel electrodes in solid oxide fuel cells and electrolysis cells

Sentencas: Zr + Y) atomic ratio decreases from similar to 0.49 before operating the cell to similar to 0.28 and the SOEC shows a pronounced decrease in percolating triple phase boundaries (TPBs).
Titulo: Comparison of microstructural evolution of fuel electrodes in solid oxide fuel cells and electrolysis cells

Sentencas: The wettability of Ni on YSZ is studied and hypotheses are presented to correlate the phenomena of Ni coarsening and Ni depletion with the cell operation mode.
Titulo: Comparison of microstructural evolution of fuel electrodes in solid oxide fuel cells and electrolysis cells
